text: The bronze altar that was before the Lord he removed from the front of the house, from the place between his altar and the house of the Lord, and put it on the north side of his altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: King Ahaz commanded the priest Uriah, saying, “Upon the great altar offer the morning burnt offering and the evening grain offering and the king’s burnt offering and his grain offering, with the burnt offering of all the people of the land, their grain offering, and their drink offering; then dash against it all the blood of the burnt offering and all the blood of the sacrifice, but the bronze altar shall be for me to inquire by.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest Uriah did everything that King Ahaz commanded.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then King Ahaz cut off the frames of the stands and removed the laver from them; he removed the sea from the bronze oxen that were under it and put it on a pediment of stone.
speaker: Narrator

text: The covered portal for use on the Sabbath that had been built inside the palace and the outer entrance for the king he removed from the house of the Lord. He did this because of the king of Assyria.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the rest of the acts of Ahaz that he did, are they not written in the Book of the Annals of the Kings of Judah?
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahaz slept with his ancestors and was buried with his ancestors in the city of David; his son Hezekiah succeeded him.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the twelfth year of King Ahaz of Judah, Hoshea son of Elah began to reign in Samaria over Israel; he reigned nine years.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did what was evil in the sight of the Lord, yet not like the kings of Israel who were before him.
speaker: Narrator

text: King Shalmaneser of Assyria came up against him; Hoshea became his vassal and paid him tribute.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the king of Assyria found treachery in Hoshea, for he had sent messengers to King So of Egypt and offered no tribute to the king of Assyria, as he had done year by year; therefore the king of Assyria confined him and imprisoned him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king of Assyria invaded all the land and came to Samaria; for three years he besieged it.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the ninth year of Hoshea the king of Assyria captured Samaria; he carried the Israelites away to Assyria. He placed them in Halah, on the Habor, the river of Gozan, and in the cities of the Medes.
speaker: Narrator

text: This occurred because the people of Israel had sinned against the Lord their God, who had brought them up out of the land of Egypt from under the hand of Pharaoh king of Egypt. They had worshiped other gods
speaker: Narrator

text: and walked in the customs of the nations whom the Lord had driven out before the people of Israel and in the customs that the kings of Israel had introduced.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people of Israel did things that were not right against the Lord their God. They built for themselves high places at all their towns, from watchtower to fortified city;
speaker: Narrator

text: they set up for themselves pillars and sacred poles on every high hill and under every green tree;
speaker: Narrator

text: there they made offerings on all the high places, as the nations did whom the Lord had carried away before them. They did wicked things, provoking the Lord to anger;
speaker: Narrator

text: they served idols, of which the Lord had said to them, “You shall not do this.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet the Lord warned Israel and Judah by every prophet and every seer, saying, “Turn from your evil ways and keep my commandments and my statutes, in accordance with all the law that I commanded your ancestors and that I sent to you by my servants the prophets.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They would not listen but were stubborn, as their ancestors had been, who did not believe in the Lord their God.
speaker: Narrator

text: They despised his statutes and his covenant that he had made with their ancestors and the warnings that he had given them. They went after false idols and became false; they followed the nations that were around them, concerning whom the Lord had commanded them that they should not do as they did.
speaker: Narrator

text: They rejected all the commandments of the Lord their God and made for themselves cast images of two calves; they made a sacred pole, worshiped all the host of heaven, and served Baal.
speaker: Narrator

text: They made their sons and their daughters pass through fire, used divination and augury, and sold themselves to do evil in the sight of the Lord, provoking him to anger.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore the Lord was very angry with Israel and removed them out of his sight; none was left but the tribe of Judah alone.
speaker: Narrator

text: Judah also did not keep the commandments of the Lord their God but walked in the customs that Israel had introduced.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord rejected all the descendants of Israel; he punished them and gave them into the hand of plunderers, until he had banished them from his presence.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he had torn Israel from the house of David, they made Jeroboam son of Nebat king. Jeroboam drove Israel from following the Lord and made them commit great sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people of Israel continued in all the sins that Jeroboam committed; they did not depart from them
speaker: Narrator

text: until the Lord removed Israel out of his sight, as he had foretold through all his servants the prophets. So Israel was exiled from their own land to Assyria until this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king of Assyria brought people from Babylon, Cuthah, Avva, Hamath, and Sepharvaim and placed them in the cities of Samaria in place of the people of Israel; they took possession of Samaria and settled in its cities.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they first settled there, they did not worship the Lord; therefore the Lord sent lions among them that killed some of them.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the king of Assyria was told, “The nations that you have carried away and placed in the cities of Samaria do not know the law of the god of the land; therefore he has sent lions among them; they are killing them because they do not know the law of the god of the land.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king of Assyria commanded, “Send there one of the priests whom you carried away from there; let him go and live there and teach them the law of the god of the land.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So one of the priests whom they had carried away from Samaria came and lived in Bethel; he taught them how they should worship the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: But every nation still made gods of its own and put them in the shrines of the high places that the people of Samaria had made, every nation in the cities in which they lived;
speaker: Narrator

text: the people of Babylon made Succoth-benoth, the people of Cuth made Nergal, the people of Hamath made Ashima;
speaker: Narrator

text: the Avvites made Nibhaz and Tartak; the Sepharvites burned their children in the fire to Adrammelech and Anammelech, the gods of Sepharvaim.
speaker: Narrator

text: They also worshiped the Lord and appointed from among themselves all sorts of people as priests of the high places, who sacrificed for them in the shrines of the high places.
speaker: Narrator

text: So they worshiped the Lord but also served their own gods, after the manner of the nations from among whom they had been carried away.
speaker: Narrator

text:
To this day they continue to practice their former customs.
They do not worship the Lord, and they do not follow the statutes or the ordinances or the law or the commandment that the Lord commanded the children of Jacob, whom he named Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord had made a covenant with them and commanded them, “You shall not worship other gods or bow yourselves to them or serve them or sacrifice to them,
speaker: Narrator

text: but you shall worship the Lord, who brought you out of the land of Egypt with great power and with an outstretched arm; you shall bow yourselves to him, and to him you shall sacrifice.
speaker: Narrator

text: The statutes and the ordinances and the law and the commandment that he wrote for you, you shall always be careful to observe. You shall not worship other gods;
speaker: Narrator

text: you shall not forget the covenant that I have made with you. You shall not worship other gods,
speaker: Narrator

text: but you shall worship the Lord your God; he will deliver you out of the hand of all your enemies.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They would not listen, however, but continued to practice their former custom.
speaker: Narrator

text: So these nations worshiped the Lord but also served their carved images; to this day their children and their children’s children continue to do as their ancestors did.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the third year of King Hoshea son of Elah of Israel, Hezekiah son of King Ahaz of Judah began to reign.
speaker: Narrator

text: He was twenty-five years old when he began to reign; he reigned twenty-nine years in Jerusalem. His mother’s name was Abi daughter of Zechariah.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did what was right in the sight of the Lord, just as his ancestor David had done.
speaker: Narrator

text: He removed the high places, broke down the pillars, and cut down the sacred pole. He broke in pieces the bronze serpent that Moses had made, for until those days the people of Israel had made offerings to it; it was called Nehushtan.
speaker: Narrator

text: He relied on the Lord, the God of Israel, so that there was no one like him among all the kings of Judah after him or among those who were before him.
speaker: Narrator

text: For he held fast to the Lord; he did not depart from following him but kept the commandments that the Lord had commanded Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord was with him; wherever he went, he prospered. He rebelled against the king of Assyria and would not serve him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He attacked the Philistines as far as Gaza and its territory, from watchtower to fortified city.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the fourth year of King Hezekiah, which was the seventh year of King Hoshea son of Elah of Israel, King Shalmaneser of Assyria came up against Samaria, besieged it,
speaker: Narrator

text: and at the end of three years took it. In the sixth year of Hezekiah, which was the ninth year of King Hoshea of Israel, Samaria was taken.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king of Assyria carried the Israelites away to Assyria and settled them in Halah, on the Habor, the river of Gozan, and in the cities of the Medes,
speaker: Narrator

text: because they did not obey the voice of the Lord their God but transgressed his covenant—all that Moses the servant of the Lord had commanded; they neither listened nor obeyed.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the fourteenth year of King Hezekiah, King Sennacherib of Assyria came up against all the fortified cities of Judah and captured them.
speaker: Narrator

text: King Hezekiah of Judah sent to the king of Assyria at Lachish, saying, “I have done wrong; withdraw from me; whatever you impose on me I will bear.” The king of Assyria demanded of King Hezekiah of Judah three hundred talents of silver and thirty talents of gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hezekiah gave him all the silver that was found in the house of the Lord and in the treasuries of the king’s house.
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time Hezekiah stripped the gold from the doors of the temple of the Lord and from the doorposts that King Hezekiah of Judah had overlaid and gave it to the king of Assyria.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king of Assyria sent the Tartan, the Rabsaris, and the Rabshakeh with a great army from Lachish to King Hezekiah at Jerusalem. They went up and came to Jerusalem. When they arrived, they came and stood by the conduit of the upper pool, which is on the highway to the fuller’s field.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they called for the king, there came out to them Eliakim son of Hilkiah, who was in charge of the palace, and Shebnah the secretary, and Joah son of Asaph, the recorder.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Rabshakeh said to them, “Say to Hezekiah: Thus says the great king, the king of Assyria: On what do you base this reliance of yours?
speaker: Narrator

text: Do you think that mere words are strategy and power for war? On whom do you now rely, that you have rebelled against me?
speaker: Narrator

text: See, you are relying now on Egypt, that broken reed of a staff, which will pierce the hand of anyone who leans on it. Such is Pharaoh king of Egypt to all who rely on him.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if you say to me, ‘We rely on the Lord our God,’ is it not he whose high places and altars Hezekiah has removed, saying to Judah and to Jerusalem, ‘You shall worship before this altar in Jerusalem’?
speaker: Narrator

text: Come now, make a wager with my master the king of Assyria: I will give you two thousand horses, if you are able on your part to set riders on them.
speaker: Narrator

text: How then can you repulse a single captain among the least of my master’s servants when you rely on Egypt for chariots and for horsemen?
speaker: Narrator

text: Moreover, is it without the Lord that I have come up against this place to destroy it? The Lord said to me, ‘Go up against this land, and destroy it.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Eliakim son of Hilkiah, Shebnah, and Joah said to the Rabshakeh, “Please speak to your servants in the Aramaic language, for we understand it; do not speak to us in the language of Judah within the hearing of the people who are on the wall.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Rabshakeh said to them, “Has my master sent me to speak these words to your master and to you and not to the people sitting on the wall, who are doomed with you to eat their own dung and to drink their own urine?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Rabshakeh stood and called out in a loud voice in the language of Judah, “Hear the word of the great king, the king of Assyria:
speaker: Narrator

text: Thus says the king: Do not let Hezekiah deceive you, for he will not be able to deliver you out of my hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not let Hezekiah make you rely on the Lord by saying, ‘The Lord will surely deliver us, and this city will not be given into the hand of the king of Assyria.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not listen to Hezekiah, for thus says the king of Assyria: Make your peace with me and come out to me; then every one of you will eat from your own vine and your own fig tree and drink water from your own cistern,
speaker: Narrator

text: until I come and take you away to a land like your own land, a land of grain and wine, a land of bread and vineyards, a land of olive oil and honey, that you may live and not die. Do not listen to Hezekiah when he misleads you by saying, ‘The Lord will deliver us.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Has any of the gods of the nations ever delivered its land out of the hand of the king of Assyria?
speaker: Narrator

text: Where are the gods of Hamath and Arpad? Where are the gods of Sepharvaim, Hena, and Ivvah? Have they delivered Samaria out of my hand?
speaker: Narrator

text: Who among all the gods of the countries have delivered their countries out of my hand, that the Lord should deliver Jerusalem out of my hand?”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the people were silent and answered him not a word, for the king’s command was, “Do not answer him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Eliakim son of Hilkiah, who was in charge of the palace, and Shebna the secretary, and Joah son of Asaph, the recorder, came to Hezekiah with their clothes torn and told him the words of the Rabshakeh.
speaker: Narrator

text: When King Hezekiah heard it, he tore his clothes, covered himself with sackcloth, and went into the house of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he sent Eliakim, who was in charge of the palace, and Shebna the secretary, and the senior priests, covered with sackcloth, to the prophet Isaiah son of Amoz.
speaker: Narrator

text: They said to him, “Thus says Hezekiah: This day is a day of distress, of rebuke, and of disgrace; children have come to the birth, and there is no strength to bring them forth.
speaker: Narrator

text: It may be that the Lord your God heard all the words of the Rabshakeh, whom his master the king of Assyria has sent to mock the living God, and will rebuke the words that the Lord your God has heard; therefore lift up your prayer for the remnant that is left.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the servants of King Hezekiah came to Isaiah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Isaiah said to them, “Say to your master: Thus says the Lord: Do not be afraid because of the words that you have heard, with which the servants of the king of Assyria have reviled me.
speaker: Narrator

text: I myself will put a spirit in him so that he shall hear a rumor and return to his own land; I will cause him to fall by the sword in his own land.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Rabshakeh returned and found the king of Assyria fighting against Libnah, for he had heard that the king had left Lachish.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the king heard concerning King Tirhakah of Cush, “See, he has set out to fight against you,” he sent messengers again to Hezekiah, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Thus shall you speak to King Hezekiah of Judah: Do not let your God on whom you rely deceive you by promising that Jerusalem will not be given into the hand of the king of Assyria.
speaker: Narrator

text: See, you have heard what the kings of Assyria have done to all lands, destroying them utterly. Shall you be delivered?
speaker: Narrator

text: Have the gods of the nations delivered them, the nations that my predecessors destroyed: Gozan, Haran, Rezeph, and the people of Eden who were in Telassar?
speaker: Narrator

text: Where is the king of Hamath, the king of Arpad, the king of the city of Sepharvaim, the king of Hena, or the king of Ivvah?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Hezekiah received the letter from the hand of the messengers and read it; then Hezekiah went up to the house of the Lord and spread it before the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Hezekiah prayed before the Lord and said, “O Lord the God of Israel, who are enthroned above the cherubim, you are God, you alone, of all the kingdoms of the earth; you have made heaven and earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Incline your ear, O Lord, and hear; open your eyes, O Lord, and see; hear the words of Sennacherib, which he has sent to mock the living God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Truly, O Lord, the kings of Assyria have laid waste the nations and their lands
speaker: Narrator

text: and have hurled their gods into the fire, though they were no gods but the work of human hands—wood and stone—and so they were destroyed.
speaker: Narrator

text: So now, O Lord our God, save us, I pray you, from his hand, so that all the kingdoms of the earth may know that you, O Lord, are God alone.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Isaiah son of Amoz sent to Hezekiah, saying, “Thus says the Lord, the God of Israel: I have heard your prayer to me about King Sennacherib of Assyria.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is the word that the Lord has spoken concerning him:
She despises you; she scorns you—
    virgin daughter Zion;
she tosses her head—behind your back,
    daughter Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whom have you mocked and reviled?
    Against whom have you raised your voice
and haughtily lifted your eyes?
    Against the Holy One of Israel!
speaker: Narrator

text:
By your messengers you have mocked the Lord,
    and you have said, ‘With my many chariots
I have gone up the heights of the mountains,
    to the far recesses of Lebanon;
I felled its tallest cedars,
    its choicest cypresses;
I entered its farthest retreat,
    its densest forest.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I dug wells
    and drank foreign waters,
I dried up with the sole of my foot
    all the streams of Egypt.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Have you not heard
    that I determined it long ago?
I planned from days of old
    what now I bring to pass,
that you should make fortified cities
    crash into heaps of ruins,
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
But I know your sitting
    and your going out and your coming in
    and your raging against me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Because you have raged against me
    and your arrogance has come to my ears,
I will put my hook in your nose
    and my bit in your mouth;
I will turn you back on the way
    by which you came.
speaker: Narrator

text: “And this shall be the sign for you: This year you shall eat what grows of itself and in the second year what springs from that; then in the third year sow, reap, plant vineyards, and eat their fruit.
speaker: Narrator

text: The surviving remnant of the house of Judah shall again take root downward and bear fruit upward,
speaker: Narrator

text: for from Jerusalem a remnant shall go out and from Mount Zion a band of survivors. The zeal of the Lord of hosts will do this.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Therefore thus says the Lord concerning the king of Assyria: He shall not come into this city, shoot an arrow there, come before it with a shield, or cast up a siege ramp against it.
speaker: Narrator

text: By the way that he came, by the same he shall return; he shall not come into this city, says the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I will defend this city to save it, for my own sake and for the sake of my servant David.”
speaker: Narrator

text: That very night the angel of the Lord set out and struck down one hundred eighty-five thousand in the camp of the Assyrians; when morning dawned, they were all dead bodies.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then King Sennacherib of Assyria left, went home, and lived at Nineveh.
speaker: Narrator

text: As he was worshiping in the house of his god Nisroch, his sons Adrammelech and Sharezer killed him with the sword, and they escaped into the land of Ararat. His son Esar-haddon succeeded him.
speaker: Narrator

text: In those days Hezekiah became sick and was at the point of death. The prophet Isaiah son of Amoz came to him and said to him, “Thus says the Lord: Set your house in order, for you shall die; you shall not recover.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Hezekiah turned his face to the wall and prayed to the Lord,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Remember now, O Lord, I implore you, how I have walked before you in faithfulness with a whole heart and have done what is good in your sight.” Hezekiah wept bitterly.
speaker: Narrator

text: Before Isaiah had gone out of the middle court, the word of the Lord came to him,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Turn back and say to Hezekiah prince of my people: Thus says the Lord, the God of your ancestor David: I have heard your prayer, I have seen your tears; indeed, I will heal you; on the third day you shall go up to the house of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will add fifteen years to your life. I will deliver you and this city out of the hand of the king of Assyria; I will defend this city for my own sake and for my servant David’s sake.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Isaiah said, “Bring a lump of figs. Let them take it and apply it to the boil, so that he may recover.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Hezekiah said to Isaiah, “What shall be the sign that the Lord will heal me and that I shall go up to the house of the Lord on the third day?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Isaiah said, “This is the sign to you from the Lord, that the Lord will do the thing that he has promised: Shall the shadow advance ten intervals, or shall it retreat ten intervals?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Hezekiah answered, “It is normal for the shadow to lengthen ten intervals; rather, let the shadow retreat ten intervals.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The prophet Isaiah cried to the Lord, and he brought the shadow back the ten intervals, by which the sun had declined on the dial of Ahaz.
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time King Merodach-baladan son of Baladan of Babylon sent envoys with letters and a present to Hezekiah, for he had heard that Hezekiah had been sick.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hezekiah welcomed them; he showed them all his treasure house, the silver, the gold, the spices, the precious oil, his armory, all that was found in his storehouses; there was nothing in his house or in all his realm that Hezekiah did not show them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the prophet Isaiah came to King Hezekiah and said to him, “What did these men say? From where did they come to you?” Hezekiah answered, “They have come from a far country, from Babylon.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “What have they seen in your house?” Hezekiah answered, “They have seen all that is in my house; there is nothing in my storehouses that I did not show them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Isaiah said to Hezekiah, “Hear the word of the Lord:
speaker: Narrator

text: Days are coming when all that is in your house and that which your ancestors have stored up until this day shall be carried to Babylon; nothing shall be left, says the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some of your own sons who are born to you shall be taken away; they shall be eunuchs in the palace of the king of Babylon.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Hezekiah said to Isaiah, “The word of the Lord that you have spoken is good.” For he thought, “Why not, if there will be peace and security in my days?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest of the deeds of Hezekiah, all his power, how he made the pool and the conduit and brought water into the city, are they not written in the Book of the Annals of the Kings of Judah?
speaker: Narrator

text: Hezekiah slept with his ancestors, and his son Manasseh succeeded him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Manasseh was twelve years old when he began to reign; he reigned fifty-five years in Jerusalem. His mother’s name was Hephzibah.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did what was evil in the sight of the Lord, following the abominable practices of the nations that the Lord drove out before the people of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: For he rebuilt the high places that his father Hezekiah had destroyed; he erected altars for Baal, made a sacred pole, as King Ahab of Israel had done, worshiped all the host of heaven and served them.
speaker: Narrator

text: He built altars in the house of the Lord, of which the Lord had said, “In Jerusalem I will put my name.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He built altars for all the host of heaven in the two courts of the house of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: He made his son pass through fire; he practiced soothsaying and augury and dealt with mediums and with wizards. He did much evil in the sight of the Lord, provoking him to anger.
speaker: Narrator

text: The carved image of Asherah that he had made he set in the house of which the Lord said to David and to his son Solomon, “In this house and in Jerusalem, which I have chosen out of all the tribes of Israel, I will put my name forever;
speaker: Narrator

text: I will not cause the feet of Israel to wander any more out of the land that I gave to their ancestors, if only they will be careful to do according to all that I have commanded them and according to all the law that my servant Moses commanded them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But they did not listen; Manasseh misled them to do more evil than the nations had done that the Lord destroyed before the people of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said by his servants the prophets,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Because King Manasseh of Judah has committed these abominations, has done things more wicked than all that the Amorites who were before him did, and has caused Judah also to sin with his idols,
speaker: Narrator

text: therefore thus says the Lord, the God of Israel: I am bringing upon Jerusalem and Judah such evil that the ears of everyone who hears of it will tingle.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will stretch over Jerusalem the measuring line for Samaria and the plummet for the house of Ahab; I will wipe Jerusalem as one wipes a dish, wiping it and turning it upside down.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will cast off the remnant of my heritage and give them into the hand of their enemies; they shall become a prey and a spoil to all their enemies
speaker: Narrator

text: because they have done what is evil in my sight and have provoked me to anger, since the day their ancestors came out of Egypt even to this day.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moreover, Manasseh shed very much innocent blood, until he had filled Jerusalem from one end to another, besides the sin that he caused Judah to sin so that they did what was evil in the sight of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the rest of the acts of Manasseh, all that he did and the sin that he committed, are they not written in the Book of the Annals of the Kings of Judah?
speaker: Narrator

text: Manasseh slept with his ancestors and was buried in the garden of his house, in the garden of Uzza. His son Amon succeeded him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Amon was twenty-two years old when he began to reign; he reigned two years in Jerusalem. His mother’s name was Meshullemeth daughter of Haruz of Jotbah.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did what was evil in the sight of the Lord, as his father Manasseh had done.
speaker: Narrator

text: He walked in all the way in which his father walked, served the idols that his father served, and worshiped them;
speaker: Narrator

text: he abandoned the Lord, the God of his ancestors, and did not walk in the way of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The servants of Amon conspired against him and killed the king in his house.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the people of the land killed all those who had conspired against King Amon, and the people of the land made his son Josiah king in place of him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the rest of the acts of Amon that he did, are they not written in the Book of the Annals of the Kings of Judah?
speaker: Narrator

text: He was buried in his tomb in the garden of Uzza; then his son Josiah succeeded him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Josiah was eight years old when he began to reign; he reigned thirty-one years in Jerusalem. His mother’s name was Jedidah daughter of Adaiah of Bozkath.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did what was right in the sight of the Lord and walked in all the way of his father David; he did not turn aside to the right or to the left.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the eighteenth year of King Josiah, the king sent Shaphan son of Azaliah son of Meshullam, the secretary, to the house of the Lord, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Go up to the high priest Hilkiah and have him add up the entire sum of the silver that has been brought into the house of the Lord that the keepers of the threshold have collected from the people;
speaker: Narrator

text: let it be given into the hand of the workers who have the oversight of the house of the Lord; let them give it to the workers who are at the house of the Lord repairing the house,
speaker: Narrator

text: that is, to the carpenters, to the builders, to the masons; and let them use it to buy timber and quarried stone to repair the house.
speaker: Narrator

text: But no accounting shall be asked from them for the silver that is delivered into their hand, for they deal honestly.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The high priest Hilkiah said to Shaphan the secretary, “I have found the book of the law in the house of the Lord.” When Hilkiah gave the book to Shaphan, he read it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Shaphan the secretary came to the king and reported to the king, “Your servants have melted down the silver that was found in the house and have delivered it into the hand of the workers who have oversight of the house of the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Shaphan the secretary informed the king, “The priest Hilkiah has given me a book.” Shaphan then read it aloud to the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the king heard the words of the book of the law, he tore his clothes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king commanded the priest Hilkiah, Ahikam son of Shaphan, Achbor son of Micaiah, Shaphan the secretary, and the king’s servant Asaiah, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Go, inquire of the Lord for me, for the people, and for all Judah, concerning the words of this book that has been found, for great is the wrath of the Lord that is kindled against us, because our ancestors did not obey the words of this book to do according to all that is written concerning us.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the priest Hilkiah, Ahikam, Achbor, Shaphan, and Asaiah went to the prophet Huldah the wife of Shallum son of Tikvah son of Harhas, keeper of the wardrobe; she resided in Jerusalem in the Second Quarter, where they consulted her.
speaker: Narrator

text: She declared to them, “Thus says the Lord, the God of Israel: Tell the man who sent you to me:
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Thus says the Lord: I will indeed bring disaster on this place and on its inhabitants—all the words of the book that the king of Judah has read.
speaker: Narrator

text: Because they have abandoned me and have made offerings to other gods, so that they have provoked me to anger with all the work of their hands, therefore my wrath will be kindled against this place, and it will not be quenched.’
speaker: Narrator

text: But as to the king of Judah who sent you to inquire of the Lord, thus shall you say to him: ‘Thus says the Lord, the God of Israel: Regarding the words that you have heard,
speaker: Narrator

text: because your heart was penitent and you humbled yourself before the Lord, when you heard how I spoke against this place and against its inhabitants, that they should become a desolation and a curse, and because you have torn your clothes and wept before me, I also have heard you, says the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, I will gather you to your ancestors, and you shall be gathered to your grave in peace; your eyes shall not see all the disaster that I will bring on this place.’ ” They took the message back to the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king directed that all the elders of Judah and Jerusalem should be gathered to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king went up to the house of the Lord, and with him went all the people of Judah, all the inhabitants of Jerusalem, the priests, the prophets, and all the people, both small and great; he read in their hearing all the words of the book of the covenant that had been found in the house of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king stood by the pillar and made a covenant before the Lord, to follow the Lord, keeping his commandments, his decrees, and his statutes, with all his heart and all his soul, to perform the words of this covenant that were written in this book. All the people joined in the covenant.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king commanded the high priest Hilkiah, the priests of the second order, and the guardians of the threshold to bring out of the temple of the Lord all the vessels made for Baal, for Asherah, and for all the host of heaven; he burned them outside Jerusalem in the fields of the Kidron and carried their ashes to Bethel.
speaker: Narrator

text: He deposed the idolatrous priests whom the kings of Judah had ordained to make offerings in the high places at the cities of Judah and around Jerusalem, those also who made offerings to Baal, to the sun, the moon, the constellations, and all the host of the heavens.
speaker: Narrator

text: He brought out the image of Asherah from the house of the Lord, outside Jerusalem, to the Wadi Kidron, burned it at the Wadi Kidron, beat it to dust, and threw the dust of it upon the graves of the common people.
speaker: Narrator

text: He broke down the houses of the illicit priests who were in the house of the Lord, where the women did weaving for Asherah.
speaker: Narrator

text: He brought all the priests out of the towns of Judah and defiled the high places where the priests had made offerings, from Geba to Beer-sheba; he broke down the high places of the gates that were at the entrance of the gate of Joshua the governor of the city, which were on the left at the gate of the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priests of the high places, however, did not come up to the altar of the Lord in Jerusalem but ate unleavened bread among their kindred.
speaker: Narrator

text: He defiled Topheth, which is in the valley of Ben-hinnom, so that no one would make a son or a daughter pass through fire as an offering to Molech.
speaker: Narrator

text: He removed the horses that the kings of Judah had dedicated to the sun at the entrance to the house of the Lord, by the chamber of the eunuch Nathan-melech, which was in the precincts; then he burned the chariots of the sun with fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: The altars on the roof of the upper chamber of Ahaz that the kings of Judah had made and the altars that Manasseh had made in the two courts of the house of the Lord he pulled down from there and broke in pieces and threw the rubble into the Wadi Kidron.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king defiled the high places that were east of Jerusalem, to the south of the Mount of Destruction, which King Solomon of Israel had built for Astarte the abomination of the Sidonians, for Chemosh the abomination of Moab, and for Milcom the abomination of the Ammonites.
speaker: Narrator

text: He broke the pillars in pieces, cut down the sacred poles, and covered the sites with human bones.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moreover, the altar at Bethel, the high place erected by Jeroboam son of Nebat, who caused Israel to sin—he pulled down that altar along with the high place. He burned the high place, crushing it to dust; he also burned the sacred pole.
speaker: Narrator

text: As Josiah turned, he saw the tombs there on the mount, and he sent and took the bones out of the tombs and burned them on the altar and defiled it, according to the word of the Lord that the man of God proclaimed when Jeroboam stood by the altar at the festival; he turned and looked up at the tomb of the man of God who had proclaimed these things.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said, “What is that monument that I see?” The people of the city told him, “It is the tomb of the man of God who came from Judah and proclaimed these things that you have done against the altar at Bethel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “Let him rest; let no one move his bones.” So they let his bones alone, with the bones of the prophet who came out of Samaria.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moreover, Josiah removed all the shrines of the high places that were in the towns of Samaria that kings of Israel had made, provoking the Lord to anger; he did to them just as he had done at Bethel.
speaker: Narrator

text: He slaughtered on the altars all the priests of the high places who were there and burned human bones on them. Then he returned to Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king commanded all the people, “Keep the Passover to the Lord your God as prescribed in this book of the covenant.”
speaker: Narrator

text: No such Passover had been kept since the days of the judges who judged Israel, even during all the days of the kings of Israel and of the kings of Judah,
speaker: Narrator

text: but in the eighteenth year of King Josiah this Passover was kept to the Lord in Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moreover, Josiah put away the mediums, wizards, teraphim, idols, and all the abominations that were seen in the land of Judah and in Jerusalem, so that he established the words of the law that were written in the book that the priest Hilkiah had found in the house of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Before him there was no king like him who turned to the Lord with all his heart, with all his soul, and with all his might, according to all the law of Moses, nor did any like him arise after him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Still the Lord did not turn from the fierceness of his great wrath by which his anger was kindled against Judah because of all the provocations with which Manasseh had provoked him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said, “I will remove Judah also out of my sight, as I have removed Israel, and I will reject this city that I have chosen, Jerusalem, and the house of which I said, ‘My name shall be there.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the rest of the acts of Josiah and all that he did, are they not written in the Book of the Annals of the Kings of Judah?
speaker: Narrator

text: In his days Pharaoh Neco king of Egypt went up to the king of Assyria to the River Euphrates. King Josiah went to meet him, but when Pharaoh Neco met him at Megiddo, he killed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: His servants carried him dead in a chariot from Megiddo, brought him to Jerusalem, and buried him in his own tomb. The people of the land took Jehoahaz son of Josiah, anointed him, and made him king in place of his father.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoahaz was twenty-three years old when he began to reign; he reigned three months in Jerusalem. His mother’s name was Hamutal daughter of Jeremiah of Libnah.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did what was evil in the sight of the Lord, just as his ancestors had done.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh Neco confined him at Riblah in the land of Hamath, so that he might not reign in Jerusalem, and imposed tribute on the land of one hundred talents of silver and a talent of gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh Neco made Eliakim son of Josiah king in place of his father Josiah and changed his name to Jehoiakim. But he took Jehoahaz away; he came to Egypt and died there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoiakim gave the silver and the gold to Pharaoh, but he taxed the land in order to meet Pharaoh’s demand for money. He exacted the silver and the gold from the people of the land, from all according to their assessment, to give it to Pharaoh Neco.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoiakim was twenty-five years old when he began to reign; he reigned eleven years in Jerusalem. His mother’s name was Zebidah daughter of Pedaiah of Rumah.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did what was evil in the sight of the Lord, just as all his ancestors had done.
speaker: Narrator

text: In his days King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon came up; Jehoiakim became his servant for three years, then turned and rebelled against him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He sent against him bands of the Chaldeans, bands of the Arameans, bands of the Moabites, and bands of the Ammonites; he sent them against Judah to destroy it, according to the word of the Lord that he spoke by his servants the prophets.
speaker: Narrator

text: Surely this came upon Judah at the command of the Lord, to remove them out of his sight, for the sins of Manasseh, for all that he had committed,
speaker: Narrator

text: and also for the innocent blood that he had shed, for he filled Jerusalem with innocent blood, and the Lord was not willing to pardon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the rest of the deeds of Jehoiakim and all that he did, are they not written in the Book of the Annals of the Kings of Judah?
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jehoiakim slept with his ancestors; then his son Jehoiachin succeeded him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king of Egypt did not come again out of his land, for the king of Babylon had taken over all that belonged to the king of Egypt from the Wadi of Egypt to the River Euphrates.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoiachin was eighteen years old when he began to reign; he reigned three months in Jerusalem. His mother’s name was Nehushta daughter of Elnathan of Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did what was evil in the sight of the Lord, just as his father had done.
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time the servants of King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon came up to Jerusalem, and the city was besieged.
speaker: Narrator

text: King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon came to the city while his servants were besieging it;
speaker: Narrator

text: King Jehoiachin of Judah gave himself up to the king of Babylon: himself, his mother, his servants, his officers, and his palace officials. The king of Babylon took him prisoner in the eighth year of his reign.
speaker: Narrator

text: He carried off all the treasures of the house of the Lord and the treasures of the king’s house; he cut in pieces all the vessels of gold in the temple of the Lord that King Solomon of Israel had made, all this as the Lord had foretold.
speaker: Narrator

text: He carried away all Jerusalem, all the officials, all the warriors, ten thousand captives, all the artisans and the smiths; no one remained except the poorest people of the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: He carried away Jehoiachin to Babylon; the king’s mother, the king’s wives, his officials, and the elite of the land, he took into captivity from Jerusalem to Babylon.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king of Babylon brought captive to Babylon all the men of valor, seven thousand, the artisans and the smiths, one thousand, all of them strong and fit for war.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king of Babylon made Mattaniah, Jehoiachin’s uncle, king in his place and changed his name to Zedekiah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Zedekiah was twenty-one years old when he began to reign; he reigned eleven years in Jerusalem. His mother’s name was Hamutal daughter of Jeremiah of Libnah.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did what was evil in the sight of the Lord, just as Jehoiakim had done.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Indeed, Jerusalem and Judah so angered the Lord that he expelled them from his presence.
Zedekiah rebelled against the king of Babylon.
speaker: Narrator

text: And in the ninth year of his reign, in the tenth month, on the tenth day of the month, King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon came with all his army against Jerusalem and laid siege to it; they built siegeworks against it all around.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the city was besieged until the eleventh year of King Zedekiah.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the ninth day of the fourth month, the famine became so severe in the city that there was no food for the people of the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then a breach was made in the city wall; the king with all the soldiers fled by night by the way of the gate between the two walls, by the King’s Garden, though the Chaldeans were all around the city. They went in the direction of the Arabah.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the army of the Chaldeans pursued the king and overtook him in the plains of Jericho; all his army was scattered, deserting him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they captured the king and brought him up to the king of Babylon at Riblah, who passed sentence on him.
speaker: Narrator

text: They slaughtered the sons of Zedekiah before his eyes, then put out the eyes of Zedekiah; they bound him in fetters and took him to Babylon.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the fifth month, on the seventh day of the month—which was the nineteenth year of King Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon—Nebuzaradan, the captain of the bodyguard, a servant of the king of Babylon, came to Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: He burned the house of the Lord, the king’s house, and all the houses of Jerusalem; every great house he burned down.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the army of the Chaldeans who were with the captain of the guard broke down the walls around Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nebuzaradan the captain of the guard carried into exile the rest of the people who were left in the city and the deserters who had defected to the king of Babylon—all the rest of the multitude.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the captain of the guard left some of the poorest people of the land to be vinedressers and tillers of the soil.
speaker: Narrator

text: The bronze pillars that were in the house of the Lord, as well as the stands and the bronze sea that were in the house of the Lord, the Chaldeans broke in pieces and carried the bronze to Babylon.
speaker: Narrator

text: They took away the pots, the shovels, the snuffers, the dishes for incense, and all the bronze vessels used in the temple service,
speaker: Narrator

text: as well as the firepans and the basins. What was made of gold the captain of the guard took away for the gold and what was made of silver for the silver.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for the two pillars, the one sea, and the stands that Solomon had made for the house of the Lord, the bronze of all these vessels was beyond weighing.
speaker: Narrator

text: The height of the one pillar was eighteen cubits, and on it was a bronze capital; the height of the capital was three cubits; latticework and pomegranates, all of bronze, were on the capital all around. The second pillar had the same, with the latticework.
speaker: Narrator

text: The captain of the guard took the chief priest Seraiah, the second priest Zephaniah, and the three guardians of the threshold;
speaker: Narrator

text: from the city he took an officer who had been in command of the soldiers and five men of the king’s council who were found in the city; the secretary who was the commander of the army who mustered the people of the land; and sixty men of the people of the land who were found in the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nebuzaradan the captain of the guard took them and brought them to the king of Babylon at Riblah.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king of Babylon struck them down and put them to death at Riblah in the land of Hamath. So Judah went into exile out of its land.
speaker: Narrator

text: He appointed Gedaliah son of Ahikam son of Shaphan as governor over the people who remained in the land of Judah, whom King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon had left.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now when all the captains of the forces and their men heard that the king of Babylon had appointed Gedaliah as governor, they came with their men to Gedaliah at Mizpah, namely, Ishmael son of Nethaniah, Johanan son of Kareah, Seraiah son of Tanhumeth the Netophathite, and Jaazaniah son of the Maacathite.
speaker: Narrator

text: Gedaliah swore to them and their men, saying, “Do not be afraid because of the Chaldean officials; live in the land, serve the king of Babylon, and it shall be well with you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But in the seventh month, Ishmael son of Nethaniah son of Elishama, of the royal family, came with ten men; they struck down Gedaliah so that he died, along with the Judeans and Chaldeans who were with him at Mizpah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then all the people, high and low, and the captains of the forces set out and went to Egypt, for they were afraid of the Chaldeans.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the thirty-seventh year of the exile of King Jehoiachin of Judah, in the twelfth month, on the twenty-seventh day of the month, King Evil-merodach of Babylon, in the year that he began to reign, released King Jehoiachin of Judah from prison;
speaker: Narrator

text: he spoke kindly to him and gave him a seat above the other seats of the kings who were with him in Babylon.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jehoiachin put aside his prison clothes. Every day of his life he dined regularly in the king’s presence.
speaker: Narrator

text: For his allowance, a regular allowance was given him by the king, a portion every day, as long as he lived.
speaker: Narrator
